metadata.title: Finding a suitable sensing time period for crop identification using heuristic techniques with multi-temporal satellite images
metadata.description: Satellite crop identification processes are increasingly being used on a large scale, both to verify the crop and to improve production. As it is necessary to study phenological data over a period of time across a large territory, a lot of storage space is needed to save the satellite images and a lot of calculation time to analyse all this information. Sensing periods are usually established based on subjective expert criteria or previous experience. However, this decision may cause several differences when discriminating crop patterns, besides not guaranteeing good precision. These processes would greatly improve if the appropriate time periods could be found systematically using the minimum number of satellite images in the shortest possible time. In this paper, we propose a new methodology to determine a suitable sensing period for crop identification using Sentinel-2 images, applying hill climbing algorithms to the training sets of neural network models. We have used the method successfully in the 2020 Common Agricultural Policy campaign in the Extremadura region, Spain. The article also describes the use of the method in a case on tobacco detection in this region.

data.title: Finding a suitable sensing time period for crop identification using heuristic techniques with multi-temporal satellite images

metadata.title: Rehabbing migraine: A pilot study on multimodal physiotherapy for pain, strength, disability, posture, and quality of life
metadata.description:
Migraine is a severe headache that causes throbbing, pulsing head pain on one side of the head. The headache phase of a migraine usually lasts at least four hours, but it can also last for days. Considering the multitude of contributing factors to migraine, a multimodal treatment may be an effective therapeutic option. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the benefits of the multimodal approach, including cervical spine traction, myofascial release, trigger point release, relaxation exercise, stretching and strengthening exercises, in the treatment of patients with migraine. Sixteen 18-55 years old individuals both male and female diagnosed with migraine were randomly assigned into two groups; Group A (control group, n = 8) who received Active ROM of Cervical and active stretching exercises only the multimodal approach or group B (experimental group, n = 8) who received the multimodal approach. The trial evaluated the cutaneous allodynia, craniovertebral angle (CVA), disability, posture, cervical deep flexor strength and quality of life at baseline, end of 4th weeks and end of 8th weeks after intervention. Following the 8 weeks, multimodal exercise program significant improvements in cervical deep flexor strength, posture, disability and quality of life were observed in intervention group compared to the control group. Finding of the present study showed that a multimodal exercise program improving problems associated with migraine in patients.

published by the  International Journal of Biosciences | IJB

metadata.title: 14. Behavioral Economics in Online Shopping: The Psychology of Discounts and Flash Sales
metadata.description: The rapid growth of e-commerce industry among the people has paved the way for online purchasing.  Online shopping is the activity or action of buying products or services over the Internet. It means using the internet, finding a seller's website, choosing an item and setting up delivery. The buyer can pay for the goods or services online with a credit or debit card or in person when the product is delivered. The term does not only include online purchases but also searching the product through online. Online shopping has been around for about twenty-five years. But its popularity has greatly increased.   Today, we can buy almost anything in online. Numerous discounts and flash sales were available while entering online shopping.  So, the people engaged impulsive and unplanned purchase.  In fact, retail experts say that online shopping will soon overtake traditional shopping in monetary terms. This paper is an attempt to examine the Behavioral Economics in Online Shopping: The Psychology of Discounts and Flash Sales.

creators.name: MUTHTHARASI – Art Literary Culture Tamil Journal,Madurai.

metadata.title: Evolutionary Centrality and Maximal Cliques in Mobile Social Networks
metadata.description:
This paper introduces an evolutionary approach to enhance the process of finding central nodes in
mobile networks. This can provide essential information and important applications in mobile and social
networks. This evolutionary approach considers the dynamics of the network and takes into consideration
the central nodes from previous time slots. We also study the applicability of maximal cliques algorithms
in mobile social networks and how it can be used to find the central nodes based on the discovered
maximal cliques. The experimental results are promising and show a significant enhancement in finding
the central nodes.

data.title: Evolutionary Centrality and Maximal Cliques in Mobile Social Networks

metadata.title: Green Biotechnology: Innovations, Applications, and Pathways to Sustainable Agriculture and Environment
metadata.description:
Green Biotechnology: Innovations, Applications, and Pathways to Sustainable Agriculture and Environment

Abstract

Green biotechnology — the application of biotechnological tools to agriculture, environmental management, and renewable resources — is central to strategies for sustainable food production, pollution remediation, and low-carbon bioeconomies. This review synthesizes current innovations (gene editing, microbial inoculants, synthetic biology, phytoremediation), summarizes evidence of agronomic and environmental benefits, and discusses socio-economic, regulatory, and ethical challenges that affect deployment. Meta-analyses show genetically modified (GM) crop adoption is associated with decreased pesticide use, increased yields, and higher farmer profits, while recent studies on microbial biofertilizers and synthetic biology demonstrate growing potential for nitrogen savings, soil health improvement, and novel bio-products. We identify research gaps (long-term ecosystem monitoring, scaling bioinoculant formulation, risk assessment of gene-edited varieties), propose priority R&D directions, and provide policy recommendations to align green biotech with circular-economy goals. Reuters+4PMC+4Nature+4

Keywords

Green biotechnology; agricultural biotechnology; biofertilizers; bioremediation; gene editing; sustainability; synthetic biology

1. Introduction

Green biotechnology encompasses the use of biological systems, organisms, or derivatives to improve agricultural productivity, restore degraded ecosystems, and produce renewable materials and energy. Distinct from medical/industrial biotechnology, green biotech explicitly targets ecological and agronomic sustainability: reduced chemical inputs, enhanced resource-use efficiency, and eco-friendly remediation of pollutants. Over the last two decades, rapid advances in molecular tools — notably CRISPR/Cas gene-editing, high-throughput genomics, and synthetic biology — have broadened what is possible in crop improvement, microbial management of soils, and pollutant degradation. Policy shifts and regulatory decisions around gene-edited crops have also accelerated deployment in some jurisdictions, illustrating an evolving governance landscape for green biotech innovations. Nature+1

This review synthesizes the state of evidence on major green biotech applications, reports quantitative outcomes where meta-analyses exist, discusses environmental and socio-economic tradeoffs, highlights technological and translational bottlenecks, and outlines pathways for research and policy that would maximize positive sustainability outcomes.

2. Major areas of green biotechnology

2.1 Crop genetic improvement (GM and gene editing)

Crop genetic modification and more recently gene editing are used to improve yield potential, stress tolerance (drought, salinity), pest and disease resistance, and nutritional traits. Benefits measured across many studies include reduced insecticide use and yield gains when pest resistance traits are effective; meta-analytic estimates indicate average pesticide reductions and yield increases following adoption of GM varieties. These gains tend to be larger for insect-resistant traits than herbicide-tolerant traits and often greater in developing country contexts where baseline pest pressure and management constraints are higher. PMC+1

Recent regulatory movements (e.g., approvals of multiple gene-edited and GM varieties in major agricultural producers) suggest accelerating commercialization of edited crops aimed at food security and import substitution goals. Such policy shifts can influence investment, seed availability, and farmer uptake dynamics. Reuters

2.2 Microbial inoculants and biofertilizers

Biofertilizers — living microbes applied to seeds, roots, or soils to improve nutrient availability, promote growth, or suppress disease — are a major green biotech tool for lowering synthetic fertilizer needs and improving soil health. Recent meta-analyses find significant positive effects of beneficial bacteria (e.g., Bacillus spp.) and consortia on crop yield parameters, nutrient uptake, and resilience against stresses. However, performance variability and formulation/stability challenges remain key translation barriers. Nature+1

2.3 Bioremediation and phytoremediation

Bioremediation leverages microbes and plants to degrade, transform, or sequester pollutants (organic contaminants, heavy metals, petroleum hydrocarbons). Techniques include bioaugmentation (adding degraders), biostimulation (adding nutrients/electron acceptors), phytoremediation (using plants to accumulate or volatilize contaminants), and engineered bioreactors for treatment. Reviews underline strong potential for cost-effective cleanup, especially when combined with monitoring and adaptive management, though site heterogeneity and contaminant complexity influence outcomes. ScienceDirect+1

2.4 Synthetic biology and metabolic engineering for green products

Synthetic biology enables design of microbial cell factories to produce bioplastics, biofuels, specialty chemicals, and novel biomaterials from renewable feedstocks. Progress from proof-of-concept to commercial products is underway, with several commercially available synthetic biology products demonstrating feasibility of replacing petrochemical pathways. This area promises circular-economy impacts but raises questions about feedstock sourcing, lifecycle emissions, and biosafety. Nature

3. Evidence of agronomic and environmental benefits

3.1 Quantitative benefits from GM crops: yields, pesticide use, and profits

Klümper and Qaim’s meta-analysis synthesizing global studies on GM crops reported average reductions of chemical pesticide use by ~37%, crop yield increases of ~22%, and farmer profit increases of ~68% following adoption (aggregated across traits and crops). These averages mask heterogeneity by trait (insect resistance vs herbicide tolerance), crop, region, and study context. Nonetheless, the consistent direction of benefits across many studies indicates substantial potential for GM technologies to reduce environmental burden while increasing productivity. PMC

3.2 Biofertilizers and microbial inoculants: yield and nutrient use efficiency

Multiple recent reviews and meta-analyses report that well-formulated inoculants (single strains and consortia) can increase yields and nutrient uptake, sometimes rivalling low-dose mineral fertilizers in effect size. A recent meta-analysis on Bacillus spp. found positive tomato yield responses, reflecting broader evidence that Bacillus and rhizobial inoculants are promising in integrated nutrient management strategies. However, variability in field responses underscores the need for site-specific testing and improved formulation technologies to ensure shelf life and field performance. Nature+1

3.3 Bioremediation outcomes: contaminant attenuation and ecosystem recovery

Review studies show effective reductions in contaminant concentrations (e.g., petroleum hydrocarbons, heavy metals via phytoaccumulation) and improved soil biological function following bioremediation interventions. Cost advantages over excavation and disposal often favor bioremediation for large or moderately contaminated sites, though complete removal of some persistent pollutants remains challenging. ScienceDirect+1

4. Case studies and comparative summary

Table 1. Representative examples of green biotechnology applications and outcomes

Application

Technology/Agent

Typical outcome / benefit

Example evidence

Insect-resistant crops (Bt)

Transgenic expression of Bacillus thuringiensis toxins

Lower insecticide use; yield increase in affected crops

Meta-analyses and long-term field studies. PMC+1

Gene-edited stress tolerance

CRISPR modulations

Improved drought/salinity tolerance (experimental)

Multiple experimental releases and field trials; regulatory approvals expanding. Nature+1

Biofertilizers (Bacillus, rhizobia)

Seed/soil inoculants

Increased N/P uptake, yield improvements; reduced fertilizer need

Recent meta-analyses demonstrate positive yield effects; performance varies. Nature+1

Phytoremediation

Hyperaccumulator plants

Removal/immobilization of heavy metals; soil stabilization

Field case studies show cost-effective remediation for specific contaminants. ScienceDirect+1

Synthetic biology for bio-products

Engineered microbes

Production of bioplastics, specialty chemicals from biomass

Several commercial products and pilot plants reported. Nature

Note: The examples and outcomes above are illustrative; local agroecological conditions, regulatory context and socio-economic factors determine realized benefits.

Figure 1. (Schematic) A conceptual diagram showing three linked green biotech pathways: (A) crop genetic improvement → yield/security; (B) microbial management → soil health/nutrient recycling; (C) bioremediation & biofactories → pollutant removal and bio-products. (Insert a diagram here in final manuscript).

5. Environmental and socio-economic tradeoffs

Green biotech promises environmental benefits but also raises tradeoffs and concerns that must be managed:

  • Biodiversity and non-target effects: Insect-resistant crops can reduce pesticide spraying, benefiting non-target organisms indirectly; however, potential effects on non-target species and resistance development require integrated pest management and refuge strategies. PMC
  • Gene flow and off-target changes: Gene flow from cultivated GM varieties to wild relatives, and off-target edits in gene-edited crops, need rigorous biosafety assessment and stewardship plans. Regulatory frameworks differ across countries in how they treat gene-edited organisms in comparison to transgenics. Reuters
  • Socio-economic equity: Seed costs, intellectual property regimes, and access to technology can create winners and losers. While meta-analyses show profit increases for adopters, seed cost and market conditions influence net benefits at farm level. PMC
  • Operational reliability of bioinoculants: Field variability, poor shelf life, and inconsistent performance limit the scale-up of microbial inoculants; investments in formulation science and quality control are essential. Nature
  • Lifecycle emissions and feedstock sourcing for bio-products: Synthetic biology products can reduce dependence on fossil feedstocks, but lifecycle assessments (LCA) must ensure net GHG benefits when considering feedstock production, processing, and land-use change. Nature

6. Key technological and translational bottlenecks

  1. Field predictability and ecological complexity: Laboratory and greenhouse gains do not always translate to field conditions; complex plant–microbe–soil interactions and abiotic variability reduce predictability. Improving mechanistic understanding and deploying multi-site trials are needed.
  2. Formulation and delivery of living products: For microbial inoculants, stabilization, controlled release, and compatibility with farmer practices are unresolved challenges.
  3. Long-term ecological monitoring: Few studies measure long-term ecosystem effects (soil microbiome shifts, resistance development) post deployment of GM/edited varieties or large-scale bioinoculant use.
  4. Regulatory harmonization and data transparency: Divergent regulatory treatment of gene editing slows international trade and technology diffusion. Transparent risk assessments and harmonized safety standards would facilitate responsible adoption. Reuters
  5. Scaling biomanufacturing sustainably: Transitioning lab-scale synthetic biology processes to economical and low-emissions industrial operations requires feedstock logistics, process intensification, and LCA-guided design.

7. Research priorities and R&D roadmap

To maximize environmental and social benefits, we recommend the following priorities:

  1. Integrated field experiments: Large, multi-locational trials that combine GM/gene-edited crops with microbial inoculants and agronomic best practices to quantify synergistic effects on yield, input use, and ecosystem services.
  2. Mechanistic studies of plant–microbiome interactions: Use multi-omics (metagenomics, metabolomics) to identify functional traits in microbial consortia that deliver reliable benefits under field stressors.
  3. Formulation science and quality control standards for inoculants: Develop stabilization methods, carrier matrices, and shelf-life protocols; establish certification standards to build farmer trust.
  4. Longitudinal ecosystem monitoring programs: Establish monitoring before and after deployment for biodiversity, resistance evolution, and soil health metrics.
  5. Circular bioeconomy pilots: Co-locate biomass feedstock supply chains, biofabrication facilities, and waste valorization systems to test scalable, low-emission biomanufacturing.
  6. Policy research on governance of gene-edited crops: Comparative analysis of regulatory regimes and trade impacts to design proportionate, science-based governance that protects health and environment while allowing innovation. Nature+1

8. Policy recommendations

  1. Support evidence-based regulation: Regulators should adopt transparent, trait- and risk-based approaches that consider both product and process while mandating post-market surveillance.
  2. Invest in public breeding and inoculant development: Public sector R&D can focus on crops and microbes with high social returns (drought tolerance, nitrogen-saving inoculants) that are less attractive to private firms.
  3. Create quality standards and certification for bioinputs: National and regional standards for biofertilizers will reduce ineffective products and protect farmers.
  4. Promote inclusive access and capacity building: Subsidies, training, and extension services ensure smallholder farmers can access green biotech benefits.
  5. Mandate lifecycle analyses for bio-products: Require LCA and sustainability assessments for large-scale adoption of synthetic biology products to prevent unintended environmental burdens.

9. Limitations of current evidence

While meta-analyses and reviews indicate robust potential, limitations include publication bias (positive results more likely reported), variability in experimental designs, and limited long-term and ecosystem-scale studies. Many recent advances (gene editing, synthetic biology pilots) have limited publicly available field data; ongoing transparent reporting and open data sharing will be vital.

10. Conclusions

Green biotechnology offers powerful tools to increase agricultural productivity, reduce environmental impacts of farming, remediate polluted sites, and produce renewable materials. Quantitative syntheses indicate clear agronomic benefits from GM crops and growing evidence for microbial inoculants and bioremediation approaches. However, to fully realize sustainability goals, investments are needed in translational research, standardized product quality, long-term monitoring, and proportionate regulatory frameworks that balance innovation with environmental protection and social equity.

Tables and Figures

Table 2. Selected quantitative outcomes from meta-analyses (summary)

Outcome

Reported value (approx.)

Source

Reduction in chemical pesticide use (GM crops)

~37% average reduction

Klümper & Qaim meta-analysis. PMC

Yield increase (GM crops)

~22% average increase

Klümper & Qaim. PMC

Farmer profit increase (GM crops)

~68% average

Klümper & Qaim. PMC

Positive yield response to Bacillus biofertilizers

Statistically significant (varies by crop)

Recent meta-analysis (Nature reports). Nature

Effective contaminant attenuation in bioremediation

Case-specific reductions reported; cost-effective vs excavation in many cases

Bioremediation reviews. ScienceDirect+1

Figure 2. (Policy and commercialization timeline — example) A timeline showing milestones: (a) commercialization of Bt cotton and other GM crops; (b) emergence of CRISPR/Cas9 gene editing (2012 onwards); (c) regulatory approvals of gene-edited crops in major markets (example: recent approvals in China and elsewhere). (Include figure with dates and annotations; refer to regulatory news summaries for exact dates). Reuters+1

References

Where available, the following references are representative sources used in this review. For convenience, web citations (links) are provided as source identifiers used in this article.

  1. Klümper, W., & Qaim, M. (2014). A Meta-Analysis of the Impacts of Genetically Modified Crops. PLoS ONE / NCBI PMC. Summary: On average, GM technology adoption reduced pesticide use (~37%), increased yields (~22%), and increased farmer profits (~68%). PMC
  2. O'Callaghan, M., et al. (2022). Soil microbial inoculants for sustainable agriculture: a meta-analysis and review. (Wiley journal) — discusses global effects of biofertilizers on yield and nutrient use. bsssjournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com
  3. Nature Communications / Voigt, C.A. (2020). Synthetic biology 2020–2030: six commercially-available products — examples of synthetic biology's commercial potential and near-term prospects. Nature
  4. Recent meta-analysis: Nature (2025). Meta-analysis of Bacillus species biofertilizer effects — demonstrates positive impacts on tomato yield parameters and points to formulation gaps. Nature
  5. Kuppan, N., et al. (2024). Eco-friendly solutions for waste and pollution management: bioremediation review. ScienceDirect. Discusses mechanisms and case studies of microbial and phytoremediation methods. ScienceDirect
  6. FAO. Agricultural biotechnology: potential, risks, and benefits to 2030 (FAO review section). Foundational overview of agricultural biotechnology’s future. FAOHome
  7. Jehangir, N., et al. (2023). The insecticidal efficacy and performance of Bt Cotton. Discusses Bt-cotton performance and regional variation. ScienceDirect
  8. Reuters (Dec 31, 2024). “China approves more GM crops to boost yields, ensure food security.” News piece reporting approval of multiple gene-edited and GM varieties — indicative of shifting regulatory landscapes. Reuters
  9. Additional reviews and research articles cited in the text include recent open reviews on green biotech innovations and several research-gate and journal review pieces from 2024–2025 summarizing contemporary developments and challenges. ResearchGate+1

data.title: Green Biotechnology: Innovations, Applications, and Pathways to Sustainable Agriculture and Environment

metadata.title: Levy Flight-based Artificial Circulatory System Algorithm
metadata.description:
LF-ACSA is an enhanced variant of the Artificial Circulatory System Algorithm (ACSA). The core idea is to strengthen the exploration phase (neural regulator) with Lévy Flight steps to increase diversity, while preserving the original ACSA hormonal regulator for the exploitation phase to maintain local intensification. As a result, the algorithm is more resistant to premature convergence on multimodal and high-dimensional problems and has a higher probability of finding the global optimum.
Original Algorithm (ACSA): DOI: 10.32604/cmes.2024.055860

data.title: Levy Flight-based Artificial Circulatory System Algorithm

metadata.title: Mutation in cytochrome b gene of mitochondrial DNA in a family with fibromyalgia is associated with NLRP3-inflammasome activation
metadata.description:
Background: Fibromyalgia (FM) is a worldwide diffuse musculoskeletal chronic pain condition that affects up to 5% of the general population. Many symptoms associated with mitochondrial diseases are reported in patients with FM such as exercise intolerance, fatigue, myopathy and mitochondrial dysfunction. In this study, we report a mutation in cytochrome b gene of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) in a family with FM with inflammasome complex activation.

Methods: mtDNA from blood cells of five patients with FM were sequenced. We clinically and genetically characterised a patient with FM and family with a new mutation in mtCYB. Mitochondrial mutation phenotypes were determined in skin fibroblasts and transmitochondrial cybrids.

Results: After mtDNA sequence in patients with FM, we found a mitochondrial homoplasmic mutation m.15804T>C in the mtCYB gene in a patient and family, which was maternally transmitted. Mutation was observed in several tissues and skin fibroblasts showed a very significant mitochondrial dysfunction and oxidative stress. Increased NLRP3-inflammasome complex activation was observed in blood cells from patient and family.

Conclusions: We propose further studies on mtDNA sequence analysis in patients with FM with evidences for maternal inheritance. The presence of similar symptoms in mitochondrial myopathies could unmask mitochondrial diseases among patients with FM. On the other hand, the inflammasome complex activation by mitochondrial dysfunction could be implicated in the pathophysiology of mitochondrial diseases.

Keywords: Immunology (including allergy); Muscle disease.

journal.title: Mutation in cytochrome b gene of mitochondrial DNA in a family with fibromyalgia is associated with NLRP3-inflammasome activation

data.title: Mutation in cytochrome b gene of mitochondrial DNA in a family with fibromyalgia is associated with NLRP3-inflammasome activation

metadata.title: NLRP3 inflammasome is activated in mononuclear blood cells from patients with major depressive disorder
metadata.description:
Introduction: Major depressive disorder (MDD) is a very prevalent disease which pathogenic mechanism remains elusive. There are some hypotheses and pilot studies suggesting that cytokines may play an important role in MDD. In this respect, we have investigated the role of NLRP3 inflammasome complex in the maturation of caspase-1 and the processing of its substrates, IL-1β and IL-18, in blood cells from MDD patients.

Methods: Forty MDD patients were selected for this study, twenty without treatments and twenty treated with amitriptyline, a common tricyclic antidepressant. Blood samples from twenty healthy volunteers were included in the study. The inflammasome activation was studied by Western blot and real-time PCR of NLRP3 and caspase 1 and serum levels of IL-1β and 18.

Results: We observed increased gene expression of NLRP3 and caspase-1 in blood cells, and increased serum levels of IL-1β and IL-18 in non-treated patients. IL-1β and IL-18 correlated with Beck Depression Inventory (BDI) scores of MDD patients. Interestingly, amitriptyline treatment reduced NLRP3 and caspase-1 gene expression, and IL-1β and IL-18 serum levels. As it is well established that oxidative stress is associated with NLRP3 inflammasome activation, we next studied mitochondrial ROS and lipid peroxidation (LPO) levels in MDD patients. Increased levels of mitochondrial ROS and LPO were observed in MDD patients, however oxidative damage was higher in MDD patients treated with amitriptyline.

Conclusions: These findings provide new insight into the pathogenesis of MDD and the effects of amitriptyline treatment on NLRP3 inflammasome activation and IL-1β and IL-18 serum levels.

data.title: NLRP3 inflammasome is activated in mononuclear blood cells from patients with major depressive disorder

metadata.title: Identifying headwater streams across the conterminous United States - spatial database
metadata.description:
Metadata can be found at: doi 10.23719/1532382 at https://sciencehub.epa.gov/sciencehub/

Headwater streams play critical roles in hydrologic and biogeochemical processes and functions, yet their spatial distribution and land cover context remain poorly understood at continental scales. Building from a high-resolution conterminous United States (CONUS) hydrography network dataset - the USGS Nahtional Hydrography Dataset-High Resolution (NHDPlus HR), we quantified the spatial extent, density, and upstream catchment characteristics of headwater stream segments across the conterminous United States (CONUS). We identified approximately 8.4 million kilometers of headwater streams (stream order 1&2), finding that 77% of the total stream network is comprised of headwaters. We modified the extent of NHDPlus HR in Indiana and portions of North Carolina and South Carolina to be consistent with surrounding stream densities of like ecoregions. The zipped ESRI geodatabase includes:

1) a gridded raster (30m resolution) of headwater catchments and associated metadata.

2) Polyline file for CONUS NHD-HR-headwaters modified stream orders 1&2 and associated metadata

3) Reference polygons that informed the inclusion or exclusion of USGS HUC12s in the analysis for Lane et al 2025 Ecosystems. Polygons include US census international boundary, two US coastline polylines, and NHD HUC12 with the exclusion flags to determine use in the analyses. 

4) a readme file describing the included files

creators.name: Golden, Heather
